title: 109_s3114
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commission on Catastrophic Disaster Risk and Insurance Act of 2006". Congress acknowledges the significant economic losses caused by hurricanes in 2005 and the potential insurance shortages. The Federal Government has provided billions of dollars for catastrophe-related losses, impacting American taxpayers. The Federal Government recognizes the economic impact of natural disasters like hurricanes in 2005, leading to potential insurance shortages and significant costs for American taxpayers. It is crucial for the government to ensure responsible risk management of catastrophes to maintain property insurance availability and protect public health and safety. The private sector's inability to provide sufficient insurance coverage poses a threat to the national economy and welfare. Multiple proposals have been introduced to address these challenges. Multiple proposals have been introduced in the United States Congress over the past decade to address catastrophic risk insurance, including the creation of a national catastrophic reinsurance fund and the revision of the Federal tax code to allow insurers to use tax-deferred catastrophe funds. However, Congress has failed to act on any of these proposals. To address the high risks from catastrophe exposure in the United States, essential technical information on financial structures and innovations in the catastrophe insurance market is needed. The most efficient approach to assessing the catastrophe insurance problem in the public policy context is to establish a bipartisan commission of experts to study the management of catastrophic disaster risk. A bipartisan commission of experts is needed to study the management of catastrophic disaster risk and report recommendations to Congress for quick action to protect the American people. Establishment of a bipartisan Commission on Catastrophic Disaster Risk and Insurance (referred to as the "Commission"). Membership details are also outlined. The Commission on Catastrophic Disaster Risk and Insurance is composed of the Director of FEMA, the Administrator of NOAA, and 12 additional members representing various sectors including consumer groups, insurance companies, state regulators, emergency officials, scientists, and university faculty. The Commission on Catastrophic Disaster Risk and Insurance includes members such as a university faculty member with risk management experience, a think tank member with risk management experience, a homebuilder with structural engineering experience, a mortgage lender, and an antitrust law expert. Members are appointed by unanimous agreement of key Senate and House leaders. The Commission on Catastrophic Disaster Risk and Insurance appoints members who consult with the President, with eligibility limitations for members of Congress or the Executive Branch. Members serve for the life of the Commission, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. A majority of members constitutes a quorum. The Commission on Catastrophic Disaster Risk and Insurance appoints members who consult with the President. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for hearings and approval actions. The Chairperson is selected jointly by leaders of the Senate and House of Representatives. The Council meets at the call of its Chairperson or a majority of its members. The Commission on Catastrophic Disaster Risk and Insurance appoints members who consult with the President. The duties of the Commission are outlined in Section 5. The Commission assesses the property and casualty insurance markets post-natural disasters and recommends legislative changes to improve market competitiveness and ensure adequate coverage for consumers. The Commission aims to provide a wide range of insurance products at competitive prices to ensure adequate coverage for consumers when an insured event occurs. The Commission aims to provide a wide range of insurance products at competitive prices to ensure adequate coverage for consumers when an insured event occurs. SEC. 6. REPORT. The Commission will submit a final report to the President and Congress within 90 days of appointing members, detailing findings and recommendations for legislation or administrative action. Recommendations will consider the insurance market structures, commercial practices, and obstacles in implementing a catastrophic insurance system. Methods to improve risk underwriting practices include analyzing risk transfer modalities, assessing private securitization of insurance risks, exploring private-public partnerships to increase insurance capacity, and evaluating the financial feasibility of national or regional catastrophe pools. Additionally, approaches for implementing a public insurance scheme for low-income communities to promote risk reduction are being considered. Methods to strengthen insurance regulatory requirements, promote public insurance policies for loss reduction in uninsured sectors, enforce structural mitigation measures, and analyze the Federal Government's role in stabilizing property and casualty insurance markets, including options like a reinsurance mechanism. The 109th Congress is considering three main legislative proposals: a Federal catastrophe fund, tax-deferred catastrophe accounts for insurers, and tax-free catastrophe accounts for policyholders. Funding options and the merits of these proposals are being discussed. SEC. 7. POWERS OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission may hold public hearings, take testimony, and issue subpoenas to gather evidence for carrying out the Act. Subpoenas must bear the signature of the Commission's Chairperson. The Commission can issue subpoenas signed by the Chairperson for gathering evidence. Failure to comply may result in a court order for testimony or evidence production, with contempt penalties. Information obtained may be kept confidential. The Commission can keep information confidential if requested, exempt from disclosure under section 552 of title 5, United States Code, and not published unless determined to be contrary to the interest of the United States. Data aggregated to protect identity can be disclosed. Members or agents of the Commission have authority. The Commission, through authorized members or agents, can take actions permitted by the Act. It can obtain necessary information from US departments or agencies and use postal services like other federal entities. The Commission can request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services on a reimbursable basis. It is also allowed to accept, use, and dispose of gifts or donations of services or property, with regulations similar to those in part 2601 of title 5, Code of Federal Regulations. SEC. 8. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission will be compensated at a rate equivalent to GS-18 pay for each day of duty. Government officers or employees on the Commission will not receive additional compensation. Travel expenses, including per diem, will be provided at authorized rates. The Commission may establish subcommittees and appoint personnel as needed. The Chairperson can appoint additional staff to carry out Commission duties. Subcommittee members and staff may be appointed and paid without following certain civil service laws. The Commission may appoint consultants and experts at rates not exceeding GS-18 pay. Federal employees can be detailed to assist the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Commission can appoint consultants and experts at rates not exceeding GS-18 pay. Federal employees can be detailed to assist the Commission on a reimbursable basis without interruption of civil service status or privilege. The Commission will terminate 60 days after submitting its report. $5,000,000 is authorized for the purposes of this Act.
